sections.content: Good ideas are everywhere. They're hiding in your frustrations, your skills, your industry experience. The myth: you need lightning-bolt inspiration. The reality: best ideas come from solving problems you or others actually have. Don't search for ideas abstractly. Look at your daily life. What's frustrating? What do people complain about? What tasks are unnecessarily difficult? Solutions to real problems = good business ideas.

sections.title: Idea Generation Methods
items: Problem-spotting: What frustrates you repeatedly?
Skill monetization: What can you do that others pay for?
Industry gaps: What's missing in your field?
Trend-jacking: Apply new trend to established market
Improvement: Make existing solution 10x better
Combination: Merge two successful concepts
Different market: Take success from one market to another

sections.content: The best starting point: your existing skills and network. Trying to build business in completely unfamiliar industry is hard mode. Leverage what you know. Developer? Build dev tools. Marketer? Marketing agency. Accountant? Bookkeeping service. You have 5-10 year head start in your domain.

sections.title: Evaluating Ideas
items: Problem size: How many people have this problem?
Problem intensity: How painful is it? (Vitamin vs. painkiller)
Willingness to pay: Will they pay to solve it?
Ability to reach: Can you access these customers?
Competition: Who else is solving this?
Your advantage: Why can you win?
Resource fit: Can you build this with your resources?

sections.title: Red Flags to Avoid
items: 'Everyone is my customer': Targeting everyone = reaching no one
'No competition': Usually means no market
'I just need 1% of market': Doesn't work that way
'It's like Uber but for X': Usually means no unique insight
Complex requiring tech breakthrough: High failure rate
Needs massive capital: Resource constraint kills most
You wouldn't use it: If you won't buy it, why would others?

sections.content: Vitamin vs. painkiller: Vitamins are nice-to-have (hard sell). Painkillers solve urgent problem (easy sell). Example: Productivity app = vitamin. Payroll software = painkiller (must have). Start with painkillers—easier traction. Add vitamins later.

sections.title: Opportunity Scoring
items: Score each factor 1-10: Market size, problem intensity, ability to pay, reach, your advantages
Multiply scores: Total opportunity score
Compare options: Highest score = best opportunity
Threshold: Only pursue if score >500
Reality check: High scores with fatal flaws still fail
Use: Framework for relative comparison, not absolute truth

quiz.question: What's better: vitamin or painkiller?
quiz.explanation: Painkillers solve urgent problems (easy sell, must-have). Vitamins are nice-to-have (hard sell). Start with painkillers for easier traction.

quiz.question: What's a red flag for business idea?
options: 'Everyone is my customer' and no clear target
quiz.explanation: 'Everyone is my customer' is red flag. Targeting everyone = reaching no one. Need specific, reachable target market.

sections.content: Most businesses fail because they build what nobody wants. Market research prevents this. But don't spend months researching—spend weeks. Get minimum viable understanding, then test with real customers. Research goal: validate problem exists, understand customer deeply, identify how they currently solve it. You're not validating your solution yet—you're validating the problem.

sections.title: Market Research Basics
items: Market size: How many potential customers?
Market segments: Different customer types with different needs
Customer demographics: Age, income, location, occupation
Customer psychographics: Values, interests, behaviors, pain points
Buying behavior: How do they make decisions?
Current solutions: How do they solve problem now?
Competition: Who else serves this market?

sections.content: The Mom Test: Don't ask 'Would you buy this?' People lie (unintentionally). Ask about their life and problems instead. Good: 'How do you currently handle X? What's frustrating about it? What have you tried?' Bad: 'Would you use my app that does Y? What features do you want?' Talk about their life, not your idea.

sections.title: Customer Interview Questions
items: 'Tell me about the last time you encountered [problem]'
'How do you currently deal with this?'
'What's most frustrating about current solution?'
'What have you tried in the past?'
'How much time/money does this cost you?'
'If you could wave magic wand, what would ideal solution be?'
Listen more, talk less: 80% listening, 20% asking

sections.title: Research Methods
items: Customer interviews: One-on-one conversations (20-30 interviews)
Surveys: Broader data collection (100+ responses)
Observation: Watch how people actually behave
Online communities: Reddit, Facebook groups, forums
Competitor analysis: What are they doing? Customer reviews?
Industry reports: Market data and trends
Landing page test: Gauge interest before building

sections.content: Finding people to interview: Your network, LinkedIn, Facebook groups, Reddit, Twitter, industry events, coffee shops (if local business). Offer $25 Amazon gift card for 20 minutes. Most people willing to talk about their problems. Need 20-30 interviews to spot patterns.

sections.title: What You're Looking For
items: Pattern recognition: Same problems mentioned repeatedly
Problem intensity: Do they actively seek solutions or just tolerate problem?
Current workarounds: How much effort goes into solving it now?
Willingness to pay: Do they currently pay for solutions?
Decision makers: Who decides to buy?
Objections: What prevents them from using existing solutions?
Red flag: If nobody has problem intensely, idea likely fails

quiz.question: What's the Mom Test?
options: Ask about their life and problems, not your idea
quiz.explanation: Mom Test: Ask about their life and problems, not your idea. People lie about whether they'd buy. Truth is in how they currently behave.

quiz.question: How many customer interviews needed?
quiz.explanation: 20-30 customer interviews needed to spot reliable patterns. Too few = unreliable data. More is better but diminishing returns after 30.

sections.content: MVP (Minimum Viable Product) isn't crappy version of your vision—it's smallest thing that delivers value and tests core assumption. Most entrepreneurs build too much. They spend months perfecting features nobody wants. MVP goal: test hypothesis fast and cheap. Build enough to learn, not enough to impress. You'll feel embarrassed shipping it. Ship it anyway.

sections.title: MVP Principles
items: One core feature: What's THE thing that solves problem?
Minimum, not minimal: Barely viable, not barely usable
Manual processes: Do things that don't scale initially
Speed: Ship in weeks, not months
Learning: Goal is validated learning, not perfect product
Iteration: Version 0.1, not version 1.0
Embarrassment: If you're not embarrassed, you waited too long

sections.content: The concierge MVP: Manually deliver service before automating. Building software? Manually do what software would do. This tests whether people want result before building expensive automation. Example: Food delivery app? Manually take orders and deliver before building platform. Validates demand.

sections.title: MVP Types
items: Landing page: Website describing product, collect emails/preorders
Concierge: Manually deliver service to customers
Wizard of Oz: Appears automated but manually operated behind scenes
Prototype: Basic working version, limited features
Video: Explainer video showing how it would work
Paper prototype: Physical mockups for testing
Start: Choose based on what you're testing and resources

sections.title: What to Include
items: Core value proposition: The ONE thing that makes it valuable
Essential workflow: Minimum path from problem to solution
Payment: Can they pay you? (Validates willingness)
Feedback mechanism: How do they tell you what's missing?
Exclude: Polish, edge cases, nice-to-haves, auxiliary features
Test: Does this test my riskiest assumption?
Guideline: Cut scope in half, then half again

sections.content: The launch-learn-iterate cycle: Launch MVP quickly. Get real users. Learn what works and what doesn't. Iterate based on feedback. Repeat. Each cycle should be 1-2 weeks maximum initially. Ten iterations beats one perfect launch. Data from real users beats your assumptions.

sections.title: Common MVP Mistakes
items: Building too much: Trying to impress instead of learn
Perfectionism: Polishing instead of shipping
No focus: Multiple features instead of one core value
No payment: 'Would you buy this?' proves nothing; charge money
Wrong metrics: Vanity metrics over learning metrics
No feedback loop: Can't learn without user feedback mechanism
Waiting: Perfect time never comes, ship now

quiz.question: What's the goal of an MVP?
options: Test hypothesis fast and cheap, validated learning
quiz.explanation: MVP goal: test hypothesis fast and cheap for validated learning. Not to impress, not perfect product. Build enough to learn.

quiz.question: What's a concierge MVP?
quiz.explanation: Concierge MVP: manually deliver service before automating. Tests if people want result before building expensive automation. Validates demand.

sections.content: Validation answers: Is there real demand for this? Opinions don't validate. Interest doesn't validate. Only money validates. 'That's a great idea!' means nothing. 'Here's my credit card' means everything. Your job: prove people will pay before investing seriously. Save months or years by invalidating bad ideas quickly.

sections.title: Validation Hierarchy
items: Lowest: Positive feedback ('Great idea!')—meaningless
Low: Email signups—slight interest signal
Medium: Waitlist with deposit—some commitment
High: Preorders with payment—real validation
Highest: Actual purchase and usage—true validation
Goal: Move up hierarchy as fast as possible
Only money validates: Everything else is just conversation

sections.content: The smoke test: Create landing page describing product like it exists. Drive traffic (ads, posts, network). Track conversion: how many people click 'buy' or 'sign up'? When they click, explain 'Coming soon—join waitlist.' If conversion rate <1%, idea problematic. If >5%, strong validation.

sections.title: Key Validation Metrics
items: Conversion rate: % of visitors who buy/signup
Customer acquisition cost: Money spent to get customer
Willingness to pay: Price they'll actually pay
Retention: Do they come back?
Referrals: Do they tell others?
Time to value: How fast do they get benefit?
Benchmarks vary: Research your industry standards

sections.title: Running Tests
items: Hypothesis: Clear statement of what you're testing
Success criteria: What results = validated?
Test design: How will you test it?
Sample size: Enough data to be meaningful (100+ minimum)
Duration: Long enough for valid data (1-2 weeks minimum)
Analysis: What did you learn? Pivot or persevere?
Iterate: Adjust and test again

sections.content: Pivot vs. persevere decision: Validated = keep going. Invalidated = change something major (pivot). Common pivots: different customer segment, different problem, different solution, different business model. Persevering with invalidated idea is expensive mistake. Pivoting on validated idea is also mistake. Data decides.

sections.title: Warning Signs
items: Low conversion: <1% conversion rate from landing page
No willingness to pay: Free is popular, paid is not
High churn: Customers don't stick around
No referrals: Nobody recommends it
Long sales cycle: Takes forever to close deals
Tiny market: Fewer potential customers than you thought
Action: If seeing multiple warnings, pivot or quit

quiz.question: What truly validates an idea?
quiz.explanation: Only money validates. Opinions, interest, signups don't prove demand. 'That's a great idea!' means nothing. 'Here's my credit card' means everything.

quiz.question: What's a smoke test?
options: Landing page describing product like it exists to test demand
quiz.explanation: Smoke test: landing page describing product like it exists. Drive traffic, track conversions. Validates demand before building. Fast and cheap.

sections.content: Pricing isn't cost plus margin—it's value capture. Price reflects value delivered, not cost incurred. Most entrepreneurs price too low from fear of rejection. Underpricing hurts: appears low-quality, attracts wrong customers, leaves money on table, creates unsustainable business. Better to price high and adjust down than start low. Can always discount. Can't easily raise prices.

sections.title: Pricing Strategies
items: Cost-plus: Cost + desired margin (common but limiting)
Value-based: What's it worth to customer? (best for most)
Competitor-based: Match or beat competition (commodity trap)
Premium: Higher than alternatives (signals quality)
Penetration: Low initially to gain market share
Freemium: Free basic, paid premium features
Start: Value-based pricing with premium positioning

sections.content: Value-based pricing formula: What's their problem costing them now? Price is fraction of that value. Example: Problem costs $10K/year. Your solution saves that completely. Price = $2-3K/year. Customer saves $7-8K. Win-win. Nobody cares about your costs—they care about their value.

sections.title: Finding Your Price
items: Research: What do competitors charge?
Ask: 'What would you pay for this?' (in customer interviews)
Van Westendorp: Ask 4 questions about too cheap, bargain, expensive, too expensive
A/B test: Try different prices, measure conversion
Start high: Easier to discount than raise
Experiment: Price isn't set in stone
Reality: You'll probably guess wrong initially—that's okay

sections.title: Pricing Psychology
items: Anchoring: First price seen influences perception (show higher 'regular' price)
Charm pricing: $99 vs. $100 (works despite being obvious)
Price tiers: Good-Better-Best (most choose middle)
Decoy pricing: Expensive option makes others seem reasonable
Bundle: Package multiple items for perceived value
Annual discount: 15-20% off annual vs. monthly (better cash flow)
Context matters: Same product, different framing = different price

sections.content: The pricing conversation: If 100% of prospects say yes immediately, you're too cheap. If 100% say no, you're too expensive. Target: 70-80% say yes. 20-30% say no = correctly priced. 'Too expensive' often means 'not convinced of value'—address value, not price.

sections.title: Common Pricing Mistakes
items: Pricing too low: Fear of rejection, leaves money on table
Competing on price: Race to bottom, unsustainable
Same price for everyone: Different segments have different willingness to pay
Never raising: Inflation and value increases justify raises
No tiers: Single option limits revenue per customer
Unclear value: If they don't understand value, won't pay
Free forever: Hard to monetize free users later

quiz.question: What should pricing be based on?
quiz.explanation: Pricing should be based on value delivered to customer. What's problem worth solving? Price is fraction of that value. Costs are irrelevant to customer.

quiz.question: What's the ideal pricing conversion rate?
quiz.explanation: Target 70-80% yes. 100% yes = too cheap. 100% no = too expensive. 20-30% rejection means correctly priced at maximum value capture.
